title: The Crossing
description: The Darien Gap. Sixty miles of jungle. Your guide just disappeared.

scenes.title: The Guide Vanishes
scenes.content:
Miguel's machete lies in the mud where you made camp. The blade still beaded with yesterday's sap. His pack is gone. The fire reduced to ash and steam.

You call his name once. The jungle swallows the sound.

Seven days into the Darien Gap. Three other migrants stir in their makeshift shelters. Ana cradles her daughter close. The old man everyone calls Abuelo coughs into his fist. The teenager with the torn Adidas shirt sits up, scanning the treeline.

"¿Dónde está Miguel?" Ana whispers.

You don't answer because you know. Miguel took the GPS unit and the water purification tablets. He took the real map, not the tourist sketch he sold you back in Necoclí. The one that showed safe river crossings and cartel checkpoints.

Moths circle your headlamp. Your stomach gnaws at itself. The protein bars ran out yesterday.

Twenty miles to the Panama border. Maybe more. The jungle doesn't care about your timeline or your money or the phone number written on the slip of paper in your shoe.

choices.text: Rally the group and move forward together
Search Miguel's abandoned gear for clues
Try to backtrack to the last village

scenes.title: United We Walk
scenes.content:
You stand and brush mud from your pants. "We keep moving north."

Ana nods first. She understands survival math. Four adults, one child, versus the jungle. Better odds together.

Abuelo struggles to his feet. His breathing sounds like paper tearing. The fever started two days ago but he hasn't complained. Won't complain. Not until it kills him.

The teenager knows about phones and soccer scores. Nothing about navigation. But his legs are strong and he carries Ana's extra water without being asked.

You divide Miguel's abandoned supplies. A half-empty bottle of iodine. Fishing line. A lighter that sparks but won't catch.

The canopy above blocks most of the morning light. Roots catch your boots. Thorns find every gap in your clothing. Ana's daughter hasn't spoken since the river crossing three days back. She walks between her mother and the teenager, holding both their hands.

A stream cuts across the path. The water runs brown with runoff. You kneel and taste it anyway. Grit and decay and something metallic that might be blood from your split lip.

"¿Podemos beberla?" Abuelo asks.

Without purification tablets, this water might kill you in days instead of hours.

choices.text: Drink the stream water and risk illness
Boil the water despite the smoke risk

scenes.title: What He Left Behind
scenes.content:
Miguel's machete weighs two pounds. The handle worn smooth from years of cutting. You test the edge against your thumb and draw blood.

His sleeping area reveals more. Boot prints leading northeast, toward the river you heard all night. Trampled vegetation where he dragged his pack. And something else.

Scratched into the mud with a stick: "FARC 2km N."

Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia. Revolutionary Armed Forces. The letters might be a warning. Or a lie to cover his real reason for running.

Ana finds you crouched over the message. "¿Qué dice?"

You don't translate. Fear spreads faster than disease in places like this.

The teenager kicks through the dead fire, scattering ash. "There." He points at something half-buried. A torn piece of paper with coordinates written in pencil. 7°N, 77°W. Means nothing without a proper map.

Abuelo coughs again. This time flecks of red hit his palm.

"We need to move," you say.

But move where? Miguel's trail leads toward the river and whatever sent him running. The main path continues north through territory marked with warnings scratched in mud.

choices.text: Follow Miguel's trail to the river
Stick to the main path despite the warnings
Hide and wait for other migrants to pass

scenes.title: The Way Back
scenes.content:
The path south looks easier. Downhill through trees you recognize. Back toward the Emberá village where you bought overpriced rice and canned meat.

But Ana shakes her head. "No volvemos."

She's right. Going back means starting over. Means explaining to your family why you failed. Means the debt collectors in your hometown have more time to find your sister.

The teenager agrees with Ana. He's been walking for six weeks, since leaving Honduras. His shoes held together with duct tape and determination. 

Abuelo says nothing. He leans against a cecropia tree and watches butterflies feed on rotting fruit. Blue morphos the size of dinner plates. Beautiful and brief.

You study the jungle ahead. Fifty-three miles of this brought you here. Seven more days minimum to reach Panama, assuming you don't get lost. Don't get sick. Don't run into the wrong people with the wrong uniforms.

A howler monkey roars somewhere in the canopy. The sound bounces off invisible trunks like a warning.

Your water bottle sloshes half-empty. Ana's daughter tugs her mother's hand and points at something moving in the underbrush. A snake or lizard. Something with scales that catches the filtered light.

scenes.title: Contaminated
scenes.content:
You cup the brown water and drink. Grit scrapes your teeth. Ana follows your lead, then helps her daughter sip from cupped palms. The teenager drinks deep, like he's been doing this his whole life.

Abuelo hesitates. "El agua está sucia."

"All water here is dirty," you tell him.

By afternoon, the cramps start. Ana stumbles first, one hand pressed to her stomach. You help her sit on a fallen log while her daughter watches with wide eyes.

The teenager makes it another hour before doubling over. Vomit spatters his torn shoes. He wipes his mouth with the back of his hand and keeps walking.

You fare better. Maybe your system adapted during the past week. Maybe you're just lucky. Abuelo shows no symptoms but he wasn't drinking much to begin with.

The path follows a ridge now. Through gaps in the canopy you see more jungle stretching north. Green upon green upon green. No roads. No clearings. No sign that humans ever passed this way.

Ana needs to rest every hundred meters. Her daughter has started crying. A soft, hopeless sound that draws insects.

You check your phone. No signal. The battery icon shows red.

Somewhere ahead, voices carry on the humid air. Spanish mixed with another language you don't recognize.

scenes.title: The Source
scenes.content:
You follow the stream uphill. Ana and the teenager support Abuelo between them. His fever broke during the night but left him weak as paper.

The water runs clearer here. Less mud, fewer insects. You find the spring where it bubbles up through limestone rocks. The water tastes of minerals and earth.

Ana's daughter drinks first. She hasn't spoken since Miguel disappeared but she smiles when the clean water hits her tongue.

You fill every container. Water bottles, a dented thermos, even a plastic bag Ana produces from her pack. Tomorrow you'll need to find more. The day after that, more again.

"Look," the teenager says.

Fresh machete cuts scar the trees around the spring. Someone else found this place recently. The cuts are clean, purposeful. Someone who knew what they were doing.

Abuelo examines the markings. "Tres días," he estimates. Three days old.

Miguel? Or someone else moving through the jungle with sharp tools and knowledge?

You hear helicopters in the distance. Military or police or worse. The sound fades north, toward Panama. Toward your destination.

Ana checks her daughter's feet. Two blisters have opened into raw wounds. Without antiseptic, infection becomes another enemy.

choices.text: Rest here and treat Ana's daughter

scenes.title: Fire and Smoke
scenes.content:
You build a small fire using dry tinder scraped from dead branches. The teenager feeds it twigs while you boil stream water in Ana's dented pot.

Smoke rises thin and gray through the canopy. In daylight it might pass for morning mist. At night it would be a beacon.

The water bubbles for ten minutes before you kill the fire and scatter the coals. Still hot enough to burn tongues but safe enough to drink.

Ana's daughter sips carefully and makes a face. Boiled water tastes flat, lifeless. But it won't kill her with parasites or bacterial infection.

Abuelo drinks his share without complaint. Everything about him suggests a man who survived worse than this. Wars, maybe. Dictatorships. The kind of history people don't discuss in mixed company.

You're packing up when you hear the motorcycles.

Two engines, maybe three. Coming from the south along the main trail. Moving fast through terrain that should slow them down.

The teenager drops into a crouch behind a buttress root. Ana pulls her daughter close and covers the girl's mouth with her palm.

Motorcycles in the Darien Gap mean trouble. Cartels use them to move product and patrol territory. Rangers and military stick to helicopters and boats.

The engines grow louder. Close enough now to hear individual gear shifts.

choices.text: Hide and wait for them to pass

scenes.title: Other Travelers
scenes.content:
The voices belong to a family from Haiti. Father, mother, teenage son, and twin girls about eight years old. They've been walking for twelve days.

Their guide disappeared too. Three days ago, near a river crossing. Took their money and their real map and vanished into the green.

"Même histoire," the father says in accented Spanish. Same story.

His wife shows you infected cuts on her arms. Thorns and branches found every gap in her clothing. The wounds smell sweet with rot.

The teenage son speaks better Spanish than his parents. He translates while his twin sisters play with Ana's daughter. Three children who found joy in Hell.

You compare notes and share water. Their route took them through cartel territory. Coca fields guarded by men with automatic weapons. They lost two days hiding from patrols.

"But we know where we are," the son says. He pulls out a hand-drawn map copied from someone else's phone. The lines show river crossings and safe camps. "Panama border, maybe four days."

Abuelo studies the map and nods. "Es correcto."

Nine people now instead of five. More voices to attract attention. More mouths demanding water. But also more eyes watching for danger and more hands to clear the path ahead.

choices.text: Join forces with the Haitian family

scenes.title: The Ambush
scenes.content:
You press yourself behind a mahogany trunk thick enough to hide a car. Ana covers her daughter's mouth. The teenager tries to make himself smaller.

Three motorcycles stop where you built the fire. Engines tick and cool in the humid air.

Boots hit mud. Spanish voices, but not Colombian accents. Venezuelan maybe, or further south. Men who traveled far to work in someone else's war.

"Aquí hicieron fuego." Someone kicks the scattered coals.

A radio crackles. The voice on the other end speaks too fast and quiet to understand, but the tone is clear. Orders. Instructions.

One of them finds your footprints in the soft earth. Follows the trail toward your hiding spot with professional patience.

Abuelo meets your eyes. His hand moves to the machete at his belt. Miguel's machete. Sharp enough to split skin and muscle.

The footsteps stop ten meters away. Close enough to smell cigarettes and gun oil.

Ana's daughter squirms against her mother's palm. Seven years old and smart enough to know that noise means death.

A boot appears around the edge of your tree. Then a leg in military surplus pants. Then the barrel of an assault rifle.

The man holding it looks surprised to see you. Like he expected something else hiding behind the mahogany.

That surprise might be the only advantage you get.

scenes.title: Strength in Numbers
scenes.content:
Nine people move slower than five, but they move with purpose. The Haitian father knows construction and navigation. His wife treats injuries with supplies hoarded from Port-au-Prince. Their son speaks four languages and remembers every face from every checkpoint.

The trail widens as you approach the Panamanian border. More foot traffic here. More hope and desperation trampled into the mud.

You reach the Río Tuquesa at sunset. The water runs fast and brown with mountain runoff. No bridge. No boat. Just a crossing point marked by rope tied to trees on both sides.

The current would sweep away anyone who lost their grip. Ana's daughter stares at the rushing water with naked fear.

Abuelo tests the rope. It holds his weight but frays at the knots. Old rope. Used by hundreds of migrants before you.

On the far bank, Panama. Safety is a relative term but better than here. The Haitian twins cling to their mother and watch the water swirl around half-submerged logs.

"One at a time," the Haitian father says. "Strongest swimmers last."

But the sun is setting and the current runs stronger in darkness. Morning might bring patrols or worse weather.

You're close enough to smell Panama. Close enough to taste it. Twenty-four hours from here, you could be calling your sister from a refugee processing center.
